title: Python Basics - Easy Quiz
description: Test your understanding of Python fundamentals

questions.question: What is the output of print(2 + 3)?
questions.explanation: The + operator performs addition on numbers

questions.question: Which of these is a valid Python variable name?
questions.explanation: Variable names can contain letters, numbers, and underscores, but cannot start with a number

questions.question: What does the 'len()' function return?
questions.explanation: len() works with strings, lists, tuples, and other sequence types

questions.question: Which of these is NOT a Python data structure?
questions.explanation: Tree is not a built-in Python data structure, though it can be implemented

title: React Fundamentals
description: Quiz for beginner level understanding of chapter CH_mod-001_1a9933be

questions.question: What is React?
options: A frontend JavaScript library for building user interfaces

questions.question: What is JSX in React?
options: A syntax extension that allows writing HTML-like code in JavaScript

questions.question: What is the purpose of ReactDOM in React?
options: To render React components into the DOM

questions.question: What is a React component?
options: A reusable piece of UI defined in JavaScript/JSX

questions.question: What is the significance of the `key` prop in React lists?
options: It defines the style of the list items
It uniquely identifies elements to help React optimize rendering
It connects the list to the backend

questions.question: Which hook is used for managing state in functional components?
What does the `useEffect` hook do in React?
options: Handles side effects like data fetching, subscriptions, or DOM manipulation

questions.question: What is the Virtual DOM in React?
options: A browser feature to speed up rendering
A lightweight copy of the real DOM used by React for efficient updates

questions.question: What happens when state is updated in React?
options: Only the component and its children that depend on the updated state re-render

questions.question: What is props drilling in React?
options: Passing data from parent to child components through multiple levels of components

title: React Fundamentals
description: Quiz for intermediate level understanding of chapter CH_mod-001_1a9933be

questions.question: What is the main purpose of React’s reconciliation process?
options: To update the DOM efficiently by comparing Virtual DOM and Real DOM

questions.question: What is the difference between controlled and uncontrolled components in React?
options: Controlled components manage their state internally, uncontrolled use props
Controlled components rely on React state, uncontrolled rely on the DOM for state
Controlled components cannot use hooks, uncontrolled can
Controlled components are class-based, uncontrolled are functional

questions.question: Why should you avoid mutating state directly in React?
options: It prevents React from detecting changes and re-rendering properly
It stops the application from compiling

questions.question: What is the purpose of React’s Context API?
options: To avoid prop drilling by providing global data accessible to components

questions.question: What is the difference between useMemo and useCallback?
options: useMemo memoizes values, useCallback memoizes functions
useMemo memoizes functions, useCallback memoizes values
Both are used for side effects

questions.question: What is React.lazy used for?
options: To dynamically import components and enable code-splitting

questions.question: What is the difference between React.Fragment and a div wrapper?
options: Fragment creates an extra node in the DOM, div does not
Fragment avoids adding extra DOM nodes, div adds one
Fragment can contain only text, div can contain elements

questions.question: What is the purpose of error boundaries in React?
options: To catch JavaScript errors in the component tree and display fallback UI

questions.question: When should you use useReducer instead of useState?
options: When state logic is complex or involves multiple sub-values

questions.question: What is the difference between React.PureComponent and React.Component?
options: PureComponent automatically implements shouldComponentUpdate with shallow prop/state comparison
PureComponent works only with hooks, Component does not

title: React Fundamentals
description: Quiz for advanced level understanding of chapter CH_mod-001_1a9933be

questions.question: What is React Fiber and why was it introduced?
options: A CSS-in-JS library for styling components
A new reconciliation engine introduced in React 16 to enable incremental rendering and improve performance

questions.question: What is concurrent rendering in React?
options: Rendering multiple apps simultaneously in one DOM
React’s ability to interrupt rendering to prioritize more urgent updates for better user experience
Rendering components on multiple servers at once
Rendering components only when requested by the user

questions.question: How does React’s Suspense work?
options: It blocks rendering of the entire UI until all data is fetched
It lets components wait for asynchronous operations (like data fetching or lazy loading) and shows fallback UI until completion
It prevents errors in child components
It improves CSS animations in React

questions.question: What is the main purpose of React’s useImperativeHandle hook?
options: To customize the instance value exposed when using ref with forwardRef

questions.question: What problem does React’s key prop solve during reconciliation?
options: It increases security of list rendering
It prevents data loss when switching pages
It helps React identify which items have changed, added, or removed for efficient re-rendering

questions.question: What is the difference between server-side rendering (SSR) and client-side rendering (CSR) in React?
options: SSR renders components in the browser, CSR renders them on the server
SSR improves SEO and initial load performance by rendering HTML on the server, CSR renders everything in the client browser
SSR is faster in all cases, CSR is obsolete
CSR only works with React hooks, SSR does not

questions.question: What is hydration in React?
options: The process of combining CSS and JavaScript into a single bundle
The process of attaching event listeners to pre-rendered HTML (from SSR) so it becomes interactive
The process of synchronizing props with state
The process of loading React apps into Web Workers

questions.question: Why is it recommended to use React.StrictMode in development?
options: To highlight potential problems like unsafe lifecycle methods, side effects, or deprecated APIs
To prevent rendering errors in production

questions.question: What is the difference between shallow rendering and full rendering in testing React components?
options: Shallow rendering renders children deeply, full rendering does not
Shallow rendering renders only the component itself without children, full rendering renders the full component tree
Both are identical but shallow rendering is faster
Shallow rendering is used in production, full rendering is for development only

questions.question: What is React’s reconciliation strategy for handling nested component updates?
options: It always re-renders the entire DOM subtree regardless of changes
It uses a diffing algorithm comparing Virtual DOM trees and re-renders only the changed nodes
It re-renders only class components but not functional components
It caches all DOM trees to avoid re-rendering
